Consider the function $f: \mathbb{R} \to \mathbb{R}$ defined by 

$$f(x) = \begin{cases} -x^3, & \text{if } x \leq 0 \\ x, & \text{if } x > 0 \end{cases}.$$

Is $f$ differentiable at $x = 0$? If yes, determine the derivative $f'(0)$.
message_2:
To determine if $f$ is differentiable at $x=0$, we need to check if the left-hand derivative and the right-hand derivative exist and are equal at $x=0$. 

For the left-hand derivative, we have:

$$f'(0^-) = \lim_{h \to 0^-} \frac{f(0 + h) - f(0)}{h} = \lim_{h \to 0^-} \frac{-h^3 - 0}{h} = \lim_{h \to 0^-} (-h^2) = 0$$

For the right-hand derivative, we have:

$$f'(0^+) = \lim_{h \to 0^+} \frac{f(0 + h) - f(0)}{h} = \lim_{h \to 0^+} \frac{h - 0}{h} = \lim_{h \to 0^+} 1 = 1$$

Since $f'(0^-) \neq f'(0^+)$, the function $f$ is not differentiable at $x=0$.
